content:
Diagnosis:
Squamous cell carcinoma of rectum, T2N0M0
Diagnosed March 2024
HPV positive, PD-L1 CPS 95

Previous medical history:
Nil significant

Current medications:
None regular

Allergies:
No known drug allergies

Current situation:
Recently diagnosed following investigation of altered bowel habit

Imaging:
MRI pelvis 15/03/24 - T2 rectal tumor at 8cm from anal verge, no extramural invasion
CT chest/abdomen/pelvis 20/03/24 - no evidence of metastatic disease

Histology:
Endoscopic biopsy 10/03/24 confirms moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, HPV positive

I reviewed [redacted name] today following recent diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the rectum. This is an unusual histological subtype, and the case has been discussed at our specialist MDT. Given the HPV positivity and high PD-L1 expression, there was consensus for treatment with concurrent chemoradiotherapy as primary treatment.

On examination today, performance status is 0. Digital rectal examination confirms a firm tumor at 8cm. No concerning lymphadenopathy. Normal liver span.

I have explained the proposed treatment plan of concurrent cisplatin-based chemotherapy with radical radiotherapy. We will arrange baseline blood tests, EDTA clearance, and audiometry prior to starting treatment. [redacted name] understands the common side effects including fatigue, diarrhea, and skin reactions. Treatment is planned to start in 2 weeks following dental assessment and radiotherapy planning scan.
